natural problem: When $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 11.  Find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3.$
natural solution: By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11,$ so \[A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 + 4 = 11.\]Then $A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 = 7.$

Again by the Remainder Theorem, when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3,$ the remainder is \begin{align} p(-3) &= A \cdot (-3)^5 + B \cdot (-3)^3 + C \cdot (-3) + 4 \\ &= -A \cdot 3^5 - B \cdot 3^3 - C \cdot 3 + 4 \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A * (x powr 5) + B * (x powr 3) + C * x + 4"
and h1 : "poly (pmod (p x) ([:-3, 1:])) x = 11"
shows  "poly (pmod (p x) ([:3, 1:])) x = -3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 11.  Find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3.$ The final Answer is -3
 ### Proof
 By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11,$ so \[A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 + 4 = 11.\]Then $A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 = 7.$
 Again by the Remainder Theorem, when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3,$ the remainder is \begin{align} p(-3) &= A \cdot (-3)^5 + B \cdot (-3)^3 + C \cdot (-3) + 4 \\ &= -A \cdot 3^5 - B \cdot 3^3 - C \cdot 3 + 4 \\
 &= -7 + 4 \\ &= \boxed{-3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A * (x powr 5) + B * (x powr 3) + C * x + 4"
and h1 : "poly (pmod (p x) ([:-3, 1:])) x = 11"
shows  "poly (pmod (p x) ([:3, 1:])) x = -3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a polynomial $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$, after applying the polynomial modulus operation with $x-3$ to $p(x)$, the resulting polynomial evaluated at $x$ is $11$. Find what the resulting polynomial evaluated at $x$ would be when the polynomial modulus operation with $x+3$ is applied to $p(x)$. The final answer is $-3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A * x powr 5 + B * x powr 3 + C * x + 4"
and h1 : "p x mod (x - 3) = 11"
shows  "p x mod (x + 3) = -3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 11.  Find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3.$ The final Answer is -3
 ### Proof
 By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11,$ so \[A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 + 4 = 11.\]Then $A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 = 7.$
 Again by the Remainder Theorem, when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3,$ the remainder is \begin{align} p(-3) &= A \cdot (-3)^5 + B \cdot (-3)^3 + C \cdot (-3) + 4 \\ &= -A \cdot 3^5 - B \cdot 3^3 - C \cdot 3 + 4 \\
 &= -7 + 4 \\ &= \boxed{-3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A * x powr 5 + B * x powr 3 + C * x + 4"
and h1 : "p x mod (x - 3) = 11"
shows  "p x mod (x + 3) = -3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For a polynomial function $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$, find the value of $x$ such that the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $(x - 3)$ is $11$. Then, find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $(x + 3)$. The final answer is $-3$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A * x powr 5 + B * x powr 3 + C * x + 4"
and h1 : "p 3 = 11"
shows  "p (-3) = -3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 11.  Find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3.$ The final Answer is -3

 By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11,$ so \[A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 + 4 = 11.\]Then $A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 = 7.$

 &= -7 + 4 \\ &= \boxed{-3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A * x powr 5 + B * x powr 3 + C * x + 4"
and h1 : "p 3 = 11"
shows  "p (-3) = -3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a polynomial function $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$, and knowing that $p(3) = 11$, find the value of $p(-3)$. The final answer is $-3$.

theorem
fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A*x powr 5 + B*x powr 3 + C*x + 4"
and h1 : "p 3 = 11"
shows  "\<exists> R. p(-3) = R \<and> R = -3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 &= -7 + 4 \\ &= \boxed{-3}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes x A B C :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = A*x powr 5 + B*x powr 3 + C*x + 4"
and h1 : "p 3 = 11"
shows  "\<exists> R. p(-3) = R \<and> R = -3"
 proof-
